elements.content: A series of heterometallic formate framework templated by amines were solvothermally prepared. They feature the formula of [AI]­[CrMII(HCO2)6] (AI = NH4H2OI and M = Mn for 1, AI = CH3NH3 I and M = Fe for 2, AI = CH3NH2CH3 I and M = Co for 3, AI = CH3NH3 I and M = Ni for 4). The title compounds exhibit isostructural niccolite architectures with differences only in the host metal ions and guest amines. Tunable ferromagnetic (FO) strength was realized in the resulting framework under the guidance of orthogonal magnetic orbital analysis of CrIII (t2g 3eg) and MII (t2g 3eg 2 for MnII, t2g 4eg 2 for FeII, t2g 5eg 2 for CoII, t2g 6eg 2 for NiII) ions. The magnetic ordering temperatures derived from the experimental magnetic measurements for 1–4 are lower than 2, 10.3, 7.6, and 22.0 K, respectively. Notably, thanks to the weak FO coupling between CrIII and MnII ions, compound 1 displays a large magnetocaloric effect bearing the maximum of magnetic entropy change (−ΔS m max) up to 43.9 J kg–1 K–1 with ΔH = 7 T and T = 3.5 K, larger than most reported transition metal-based complexes and commercial gadolinium gallium garnet (Gd3Ga5O12) (−ΔS m max = 38.4 J kg–1 K–1 with ΔH = 7 T). From 1, 2/3, to 4, an enhancement of the magnetic ordering temperature is observable due to the increasing strength of FO interactions between CrIII and MII ions. Our work provides a successful instance to modulate the strength of FO exchange via analyzing the orthogonal magnetic orbitals of heterometallic ions.

elements.content: Recent years have seen the flourishing development of molecular magnetic materials because of their intrinsic characteristics compared with traditional materials. The assembly of suitable spin carriers and bridges provides extra freedom to the fabrication of desirable products driven by the crystal and magnetic engineering strategies. Among the various explored molecular magnetic materials, the organic amine-directed metal formate frameworks have gained tremendous attention of magnetochemist for their diverse magnetic behaviors, together with the potential multifunction. For example, Wang and co-workers have well-summarized the structural features of organoamines-directed metal formate architecture and the structure-related magnetism. The coexistence of magnetic ordering and electric ordering has also been achieved in the organoamines-directed metal-formate framework with perovskite structure. The efficiency of formate in the construction of weak ferromagnet has also been reviewed by Gao and co-worker.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Recent years have seen the flourishing development of molecular magnetic materials because of their intrinsic characteristics compared with traditional materials. The assembly of suitable spin carriers and bridges provides extra freedom to the fabrication of desirable products driven by the crystal and magnetic engineering strategies. Among the various explored molecular magnetic materials, the organic amine-directed metal formate frameworks have gained tremendous attention of magnetochemist for their diverse magnetic behaviors, together with the potential multifunction. For example, Wang and co-workers have well-summarized the structural features of organoamines-directed metal formate architecture and the structure-related magnetism. The coexistence of magnetic ordering and electric ordering has also been achieved in the organoamines-directed metal-formate framework with perovskite structure. The efficiency of formate in the construction of weak ferromagnet has also been reviewed by Gao and co-worker.

elements.content: A view of literature indicated that pure formato–transitional metal (TM) systems usually feature anti-ferromagnetism and weak ferromagnetism (or canted anti-ferromagnetism). We and others have demonstrated that the introduction of a suitable (paramagnetic) trivalent ion to pure format-TM systems would generate heterometallic formate frame with niccolite structure. They feature the general formula of [AI]­[MIIIMII(HCO2)6] with abundant magnetism, together with the captivating order–disorder phase transition of various guest amines and potential magneto-dielectric response. For example, Néel N-Type ferrimagnet and exchange bias (EB) is observable in [NH2(CH3)2]­[FeIIIFeII(HCO2)6]. Further characterisations indicates that the disorder–order transition of [NH2(CH3)2]I guest provides opportunities for the search of molecular multiferroics. Substituting the FeII with CoII and MnII generates isostructural architecture with Néel Q-type ferrimagnet (FeIII–CoII) and canted anti-ferromagnet (FeIII–MnII), and their magnetic structures have also been confirmed by neutron diffraction. [(CH3CH2)2NH2]­[FeIIIFeII(HCOO)6] features tunable EB fields and four distinct kinds of bistability with response to dielectric and magnetic stimulation. Large magnetocaloric effect (MCE) is achieved in [AI]­[CrIIIMnII(HCOO)6] (A = NH2(CH3)2 and CH3NH3) thanks to the weak magnetic interactions between CrIII and MnII ions, which gives us a hint that we could mediate the strength of magnetic coupling in niccolite-like heterometallic formate architecture under the guidence of orthogonal magnetic orbital analysis of prototype compounds.

[(CH3CH2)2NH2][FeIIIFeII(HCOO)6] features tunable EB fields and four distinct kinds of bistability with response to dielectric and magnetic stimulation. elements.content: As our continuous search for investigating the magnetism of heterometallic formate frame, herein, we report four amines-templated heterometallic formate frame with the general formula of [AI]­[CrMII(HCO2)6] (AI = NH4H2OI and M = Mn for 1, AI = CH3NH3 I and M = Fe for 2, AI = CH3NH2CH3 I and M = Co for 3, AI = CH3NH3 I and M = Ni for 4). It is notable that the resulting isostructural niccolite-like structure features tunable ferromagnetic (FO) strength driven by orthogonal magnetic orbital analysis of CrIII (t2g 3eg) and MII (t2g 3eg 2 for MnII, t2g 4eg 2 for FeII, t2g 5eg 2 for CoII, t2g 6eg 2 for NiII) ions. The magnetic ordering temperatures for 1–4 are lower than 2, 10.3, 7.6, and 22.0 K, respectively. Thanks to the weak FO coupling between CrIII and MnII ions, 1 exhibits a high MCE bearing the maximum of magnetic entropy change (−ΔS m max) up to 43.9 J kg–1 K–1 (ΔH = 7 T and T = 3.5 K), larger than most of the reported TM-based complexes and commercial gadolinium gallium garnet (Gd3Ga5O12) (−ΔS m max = 38.4 J kg–1 K–1 with ΔH = 7 T). By contrast, the enhancement of the magnetic ordering temperature in form 1, 2/3, to 4 is observable due to the increasing strength of FO interactions between CrIII and MII ions.

elements.content: All reagents are commercially available analytical grade, but the formate acid is 86%. The elemental analyses (EA) were characterized on a PerkinElmer 2400LS II elemental analyzer. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data was characterized on a Rigaku D/Max-2500 diffractometerfor a Cu-target tube and a graphite monochromator (40 kV, 100 mA). Simulated PXRD spectra were derived from modulating the single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) data via the Mercury software. Magnetic data were characterized on a Quantum Design MPMS-XL SQUID magnetometer with crushed crystalline sample. The data were corrected via Pascal’s constants to count the diamagnetic susceptibility.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Characterizations

All reagents are commercially available analytical grade, but the formate acid is 86%. The elemental analyses (EA) were characterized on a PerkinElmer 2400LS II elemental analyzer. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data was characterized on a Rigaku D/Max-2500 diffractometerfor a Cu-target tube and a graphite monochromator (40 kV, 100 mA). Simulated PXRD spectra were derived from modulating the single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) data via the Mercury software. Magnetic data were characterized on a Quantum Design MPMS-XL SQUID magnetometer with crushed crystalline sample. The data were corrected via Pascal's constants to count the diamagnetic susceptibility.

elements.content: The mixture of Cr­(NO3)3·9H2O (1.2 g, 3 mmol), MnCl2·4H2O (0.39 g, 2 mmol), formic acid (6 mL), formamide (6 mL), and water (3 mL) in a sealed Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel was heated at 70 °C for 2 d and then cooled to ambitent temperature. Rose block crystals of 1 was obtained in an ∼30% yield based on Cr salt. Theoretical EA (%) for C6H12CrMnNO13 (413.09): C, 17.45; N, 3.39; H, 2.93. Experimental: C, 17.63; N, 3.16; H, 3.21.

Because the niccolite structural heterometallic formate frameworks have been reported, the structural descriptions of 1–4 are simplified. SCXRD and topological analysis indicate that the metal ions (MIII or MII) located in (4966) and (41263) nodes. The formate anions bridged two metal ions in (4966) and (41263) nodes in anti–anti mode. All metal ions exhibit octahedral geometry coordinated by six O atoms from formate ligands. The metal ions in (4966) node connected six metal ions in (41263) nodes through formate ligands to form a super-trigonal prism, while the (41263) node linked six (4966) nodes to result in a superoctahedron (a). The MII ions occupy (4966) nodes, while the MIII ions occupy (41263) nodes. The AI cations serve as charge balancer to fill in the cavities of the cage constructed by 11 metal ions and 19 formate ligands (b–d). In 1, the ammonium cations located in center of the cavities with one disorder water molecule swinging in two sides of the cations (d). The occupancy of the water molecule was approved by the equivalent isotropic atomic displacement parameters (U eq) and elemental analyses. The water and ammonium were stabilized by H bonds. In 2 and 4, the N atom of CH3NH3 I displays threefold disorder, while the methyl C atom of CH3NH3 I has a twofold disorder along the two sides of the plane generated by the disordered N atoms (b). The CH3NH2CH3 I cation in 3 behaved like the CH3NH3 I in 2 but without the twofold disorder of the methyl group (c). The charger blancers (AI) are close to MII ions with same coordinates position along c direction ().
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Description of Crystal Structure

Because the niccolite structural heterometallic formate frameworks have been reported, the structural descriptions of 1-4 are simplified. SCXRD and topological analysis indicate that the metal ions (MIII or MII) located in (4966) and (41263) nodes. The formate anions bridged two metal ions in (4966) and (41263) nodes in anti-anti mode. All metal ions exhibit octahedral geometry coordinated by six O atoms from formate ligands. The metal ions in (4966) node connected six metal ions in (41263) nodes through formate ligands to form a super-trigonal prism, while the (41263) node linked six (4966) nodes to result in a superoctahedron (a). The MII ions occupy (4966) nodes, while the MIII ions occupy (41263) nodes. The AI cations serve as charge balancer to fill in the cavities of the cage constructed by 11 metal ions and 19 formate ligands (b-d). In 1, the ammonium cations located in center of the cavities with one disorder water molecule swinging in two sides of the cations (d). The occupancy of the water molecule was approved by the equivalent isotropic atomic displacement parameters (U eq) and elemental analyses. The water and ammonium were stabilized by H bonds. In 2 and 4, the N atom of CH3NH3 I displays threefold disorder, while the methyl C atom of CH3NH3 I has a twofold disorder along the two sides of the plane generated by the disordered N atoms (b). The CH3NH2CH3 I cation in 3 behaved like the CH3NH3 I in 2 but without the twofold disorder of the methyl group (c). The charger blancers (AI) are close to MII ions with same coordinates position along c direction ().

elements.content: Although the structure of 1 has been reported, the magnetic and magnetocaloric investigation of 1 has not been conducted. Magnetic properties of 1–4 were studied on powder samples, and the phase purity is confirmed by the agreement between experimental PXRD curves and the fitted ones (Figures S1–S3). The magnetic susceptibility (χ) data are characterized in 2–300 K under 1 kOe field. The temperature-dependent χm T plot of 1 is present in a. The experimental χm T product of 6.57 cm3 mol–1 K at 300 K for 1 matches with the spin-only values (g = 2.00) of one isolated CrIII and one MnII. When cooled, the χm T product increases gradually before 40 K, and then it quickly rises to 32.95 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K. The χm data among 2–300 K can be fitted by the Curie–Weiss law, giving C = 6.53 cm3 mol–1 K and θ = 1.53 K (Figure. S4). The small positive θ suggests weak FO interactions in 1. However, no saturation of magnetizations was observed at low temperature under 0.1 T excluding long-range order (LRO) above 2 K. Magnetizations among 2–10 K were also gauged (a). At low fields (<0.5 T), the magnetization at 2 K increases sharply and increases gradually to 7.88 Nβ at 7 T, close to the theoretical value of 8.0 Nβ for one CrIII and one MnII. All of these magnetic behaviors indicate weak FO couplings among neighboring metal ions. The high magnetic density (or large metal/ligand mass ratio) and weak FO interactions between the CrIII–MnII ions in 1 hold great promise for low-temperature magnetic cooler.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetism Studies

Although the structure of 1 has been reported, the magnetic and magnetocaloric investigation of 1 has not been conducted. Magnetic properties of 1-4 were studied on powder samples, and the phase purity is confirmed by the agreement between experimental PXRD curves and the fitted ones (Figures S1-S3). The magnetic susceptibility (χ) data are characterized in 2-300 K under 1 kOe field. The temperature-dependent χm T plot of 1 is present in a. The experimental χm T product of 6.57 cm3 mol-1 K at 300 K for 1 matches with the spin-only values (g = 2.00) of one isolated CrIII and one MnII. When cooled, the χm T product increases gradually before 40 K, and then it quickly rises to 32.95 cm3 mol-1 K at 2 K. The χm data among 2-300 K can be fitted by the Curie-Weiss law, giving C = 6.53 cm3 mol-1 K and θ = 1.53 K (Figure. S4). The small positive θ suggests weak FO interactions in 1. However, no saturation of magnetizations was observed at low temperature under 0.1 T excluding long-range order (LRO) above 2 K. Magnetizations among 2-10 K were also gauged (a). At low fields (<0.5 T), the magnetization at 2 K increases sharply and increases gradually to 7.88 Nβ at 7 T, close to the theoretical value of 8.0 Nβ for one CrIII and one MnII. All of these magnetic behaviors indicate weak FO couplings among neighboring metal ions. The high magnetic density (or large metal/ligand mass ratio) and weak FO interactions between the CrIII-MnII ions in 1 hold great promise for low-temperature magnetic cooler.

elements.content: As a vital parameter in evaluating MCE, the value of magnetic entropy change (−ΔS m) could be derived from the experimental data via the following equation ΔS m(T)ΔH = ∫[∂M(T,H)/∂T]H dH. The field and temperature-dependent −ΔS m values of 1 are offered in b, with a maximum value of −ΔS m max = 43.9 J kg–1 K–1 (18.1 J mol–1 K–1) at 3.5 K with ΔH = 7 T. The −ΔS m max is lower than the value of 26.4 J mol–1 K–1 for magnetically non-interacting CrIII and MnII ions (calculated by R[ln­(2 × 5/2 + 1) + ln­(2 × 2/3 + 1)], and R represents the gas constant). The −ΔS m max of 1 is comparable with the anti-ferromagnetic (AF) [CH3NH2CH3]­[CrMn­(HCOO)6] (M r = 423.1 g mol–1, −ΔS m max = 43.9 J kg–1 K–1) but smaller than the weak FO [CH3NH3]­[CrMn­(HCOO)6] (M r = 409.1 g mol–1, −ΔS m max = 48.2 J kg–1 K–1) with similar formula weight. Thus, the deviation between experimental and theoretical value may be ascribed to the anisotropy of single ions or crystalline nature or short-range order triggered by the weak magnetic couplings between the CrIII and MnII ions. Notably, the −ΔS m max value of 1 is excellent and higher than most of known metal clusters, Gd-based complexes, and commercial gadolinium gallium garnet (Gd3Ga5O12) (−ΔS m max = 38.4 J kg–1 K–1 with ΔH = 7 T). Notably, formate takes a key role in achieving large MCE, which not only realizes weak FO interactions between adjacent metal ions to hinder LRO but also maintains high magnetic density. Compared with the broadly investigated GdIII-based molecular magnetic coolers, less progress has been achieved in 3d complexes due to the huge difficulties in achieving weak magnetic interactions between targeted 3d ions and simultaneously holding high magnetic density (). The niccolite structure provides a new platform for the design of rare polymeric 3d complexes with excellent MCE via the heterometallic strategy.
elements.clean_text: As a vital parameter in evaluating MCE, the value of magnetic entropy change (-ΔS m) could be derived from the experimental data via the following equation ΔS m(T)ΔH  = ∫[∂M(T,H)/∂T]HdH. The field and temperature-dependent -ΔS m values of 1 are offered in b, with a maximum value of -ΔS m max = 43.9 J kg-1 K-1 (18.1 J mol-1 K-1) at 3.5 K with ΔH = 7 T. The -ΔS m max is lower than the value of 26.4 J mol-1 K-1 for magnetically non-interacting CrIII and MnII ions (calculated by R[ln(2 × 5/2 + 1) + ln(2 × 2/3 + 1)], and R represents the gas constant). The -ΔS m max of 1 is comparable with the anti-ferromagnetic (AF) [CH3NH2CH3][CrMn(HCOO)6] (M r = 423.1 g mol-1, -ΔS m max = 43.9 J kg-1 K-1) but smaller than the weak FO [CH3NH3][CrMn(HCOO)6] (M r = 409.1 g mol-1, -ΔS m max = 48.2 J kg-1 K-1) with similar formula weight. Thus, the deviation between experimental and theoretical value may be ascribed to the anisotropy of single ions or crystalline nature or short-range order triggered by the weak magnetic couplings between the CrIII and MnII ions. Notably, the -ΔS m max value of 1 is excellent and higher than most of known metal clusters, Gd-based complexes, and commercial gadolinium gallium garnet (Gd3Ga5O12) (-ΔS m max = 38.4 J kg-1 K-1 with ΔH = 7 T). Notably, formate takes a key role in achieving large MCE, which not only realizes weak FO interactions between adjacent metal ions to hinder LRO but also maintains high magnetic density. Compared with the broadly investigated GdIII-based molecular magnetic coolers, less progress has been achieved in 3d complexes due to the huge difficulties in achieving weak magnetic interactions between targeted 3d ions and simultaneously holding high magnetic density (). The niccolite structure provides a new platform for the design of rare polymeric 3d complexes with excellent MCE via the heterometallic strategy.

The χm T product for 2 at 300 K is 5.21 cm3 K mol–1 (a), slightly above the expected value of 4.88 cm3 K mol–1 for one non-interacting CrIII ion and one FeII ion (S = 2.0, g = 2.0), indicating the contribution of the unquenching orbital angular moments of FeII ions. Simulating the χm data among 30–300 K by the Curie–Weiss law yields C = 5.08 cm3 mol–1 K and θ = 10.08 K (Figure S4). The positive θ further confirms FO couplings in 2. The FO interactions in 2 could be explained by the orbital orthogonal theory, in which the magentic couplings of the six FO J t2g‑eg interactions are stronger than the six AF J t2g‑t2g interactions. The fast increase of magnetization at low temperature suggested the presence of LRO in 2. A split-up was present between the field-cooled (FC) and zero-field-cooled (ZFC) plot below 10.3 K (c), confirming the presence of LRO. The hysteresis loop was clearly observable at 2 K (b). The coercivity is 784 Oe. The saturated magnetization under 5 T at 2 K is 5.0 Nβ (b), lower than the theoretical value of 7.0 Nβ for one CrIII and one FeII ion. The magnetic unsaturation even at 5 T may be due to the single-ion anisotropy of FeII ions.

elements.content: When cooled, the χm T products for 3 gradually decline from ambient temperature value to minimums at 70 K, then rise to a maximum before the final dropping (a). Fitting the χm data among 100–300 K by Curie–Weiss law provides C = 5.89 cm3 mol–1 K and θ = −7.54 K (Figure S4). The C value is obviously higher than the value 3.75 cm3 K mol–1 for the sum of magnetically isolated spin-only CoII ion (S = 3/2, g = 2.0) and CrIII ion, suggesting the contribution of the unquenched orbital angular momentum of CoII ion. The decline of χm T at high temperature is due to the spin–orbit coupling of CoII, which could give rise to a negative θ value of ca. −20 K. The phase transition temperature (T c) of 7.6 K for 3 was confirmed by the deviation of the FC and ZFC magnetization (c). And tendency of field-dependent magnetization plots at 2 K suggested 3 is a soft magnet at low temperature (b).

elements.content: The niccolite structural heterometallic formates feature tunable structural constituents for trivalent, divalent, and the guest cations. With NH4H2OI, CH3NH3 I, and CH3NH2CH3 I as template, the trivalent and divalent metal ions in 1–4 occupy the (41263) and (4966) nodes, respectively. That suggested that the distinct coordination bond lengths between trivalent metal ions CrIII and divalent ions (MnII, FeII, CoII, NiII) could be recognized in the process of assembly. Compared with the structure of homometallic divalent metal formate with high template-dependence, the structure of the heterometallic MIII–MII metal formate are predictable. The formate acid and amide as mixed solvent are universal in the formation of niccolite structural heterometallic formates.
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

The niccolite structural heterometallic formates feature tunable structural constituents for trivalent, divalent, and the guest cations. With NH4H2OI, CH3NH3 I, and CH3NH2CH3 I as template, the trivalent and divalent metal ions in 1-4 occupy the (41263) and (4966) nodes, respectively. That suggested that the distinct coordination bond lengths between trivalent metal ions CrIII and divalent ions (MnII, FeII, CoII, NiII) could be recognized in the process of assembly. Compared with the structure of homometallic divalent metal formate with high template-dependence, the structure of the heterometallic MIII-MII metal formate are predictable. The formate acid and amide as mixed solvent are universal in the formation of niccolite structural heterometallic formates.

elements.content: Magnetic study also indicated the diversity of the niccolite heterometallic formates. FO interactions were found between CrIII–FeII/CoII/NiII with CH3NH3 I and CH3NH2CH3 I as charge balancer with T c from 7.6 to 22.0 K. AF interactions were found in the FeIII–MII or homometallic metal formate, leading to canted AF or ferrimagnetic state. And N-type ferrimagnetism and exchange bias were present in the mixed valence complex [NH2(CH3)2]­[FeIIIFeII(HCO2)6], while the magnetic interactions between CrIII and MnII are very weak and sensitive to the protonated amine utilized. The FO contributions are increased via changing the amines from CH3NH2CH3 I, CH3NH3 I to NH4H2OI. That may be because the rotation of N atoms of the corresponding amine in 004 plane is weakened from CH3NH2CH3 I to CH3NH3 I and frozen to NH4H2OI, leading to an increase of c axis and decrease of a and b axes. The distances of the CrIII–MnII ions do not follow the trend of c axis. And it is found that adjacent CrIII–CrIII distances increase obviously from CH3NH2CH3 I, CH3NH3 I to NH4H2OI, while MnII–MnII distances decrease, and meanwhile the dihedral angles between Mn1 O2 C1 and the plane of the formate O1 C1 O2 also decrease from 12.4° to 5.77°. The serial structural changes aforementioned make the magnetic interactions vary from AF to FO ones.

FO interactions were found between CrIII-FeII/CoII/NiII with CH3NH3 I and CH3NH2CH3 I as charge balancer with T c from 7.6 to 22.0 K. AF interactions were found in the FeIII-MII or homometallic metal formate, leading to canted AF or ferrimagnetic state. And N-type ferrimagnetism and exchange bias were present in the mixed valence complex [NH2(CH3)2][FeIIIFeII(HCO2)6], while the magnetic interactions between CrIII and MnII are very weak and sensitive to the protonated amine utilized. The FO contributions are increased via changing the amines from CH3NH2CH3 I, CH3NH3 I to NH4H2OI. That may be because the rotation of N atoms of the corresponding amine in 004 plane is weakened from CH3NH2CH3 I to CH3NH3 I and frozen to NH4H2OI, leading to an increase of c axis and decrease of a and b axes. The distances of the CrIII-MnII ions do not follow the trend of c axis. And it is found that adjacent CrIII-CrIII distances increase obviously from CH3NH2CH3 I, CH3NH3 I to NH4H2OI, while MnII-MnII distances decrease, and meanwhile the dihedral angles between Mn1 O2 C1 and the plane of the formate O1 C1 O2 also decrease from 12.4° to 5.77°. The serial structural changes aforementioned make the magnetic interactions vary from AF to FO ones.

elements.content: The magnetic nature and strength of the magnetic couplings between CrIII and MII could be comprehended by the orbital orthogonal theory in binary-metal prussian blue analogues (PBAs). Three distinct kinds of magnetic orbital couplings exist among 3d ions of the first row of the periodic table in an octahedral field: J eg‑eg, J t2g‑eg, and J t2g‑t2g (). According to magnetic theory, the couplings between orthogonal magnetic orbitals are FO; therefore, J t2g‑eg is FO, while J eg‑eg and J t2g‑t2g are AF. For the eg orbitals (d x 2–y 2 and d z 2 ) extending to the vertexes of the octahedra, the absolute value of the three kinds of couplings should be |J AF|t2g‑t2g < |JF |t2g‑eg < |J AF|eg‑eg. Thus, strongest FO couplings were found in CrIII–NiII complexes, because the magnetic couplings are six J t2g‑eg. From CrIII–NiII, CrIII–CoII, CrIII–FeII, and CrIII–MnII, the number of the AF contributions of J t2g‑t2g increased gradually; thus, the strength of FO couplings of those complexes decreased and tuned to very weak magnetic coupling in 1-CrMn, which is well-reflected on the T c directly (). Compared the CrMn and CrNi complexes without different amines, it is found that the counterions have less influence on θ value and phase-transition temperature, while the T c and θ value of the CrCo and CrFe complexes with anisotropic MII ions (FeII and CoII) are more sensitive with the counterions than the NiII and MnII complexes. That suggested that the anisotropy originated from spin–orbit coupling of the MII ions also has its influence on θ and T c. However, compared with the intrinsic influence of orbital interactions, the influence of protonated amines guest on the T c is limited. And a general tendency that the ferromagnetic interactions between CrIII–MII are inceracring from MnII, FeII/CoII to NiII could be found with same or different amines.
elements.clean_text: The magnetic nature and strength of the magnetic couplings between CrIII and MII could be comprehended by the orbital orthogonal theory in binary-metal prussian blue analogues (PBAs). Three distinct kinds of magnetic orbital couplings exist among 3d ions of the first row of the periodic table in an octahedral field: J eg-eg, J t2g-eg, and J t2g-t2g (). According to magnetic theory, the couplings between orthogonal magnetic orbitals are FO; therefore, J t2g-eg is FO, while J eg-eg and J t2g-t2g are AF. For the eg orbitals (d x 2-y 2  and d z 2 ) extending to the vertexes of the octahedra, the absolute value of the three kinds of couplings should be |J AF|t2g-t2g < |JF |t2g-eg < |J AF|eg-eg. Thus, strongest FO couplings were found in CrIII-NiII complexes, because the magnetic couplings are six J t2g-eg. From CrIII-NiII, CrIII-CoII, CrIII-FeII, and CrIII-MnII, the number of the AF contributions of J t2g-t2g increased gradually; thus, the strength of FO couplings of those complexes decreased and tuned to very weak magnetic coupling in 1-CrMn, which is well-reflected on the T c directly (). Compared the CrMn and CrNi complexes without different amines, it is found that the counterions have less influence on θ value and phase-transition temperature, while the T c and θ value of the CrCo and CrFe complexes with anisotropic MII ions (FeII and CoII) are more sensitive with the counterions than the NiII and MnII complexes. That suggested that the anisotropy originated from spin-orbit coupling of the MII ions also has its influence on θ and T c. However, compared with the intrinsic influence of orbital interactions, the influence of protonated amines guest on the T c is limited. And a general tendency that the ferromagnetic interactions between CrIII-MII are inceracring from MnII, FeII/CoII to NiII could be found with same or different amines.

A series of heterometallic formate framework templated by distinct amines has been solvothermally prepared. They feature the general formula of [AI]­[CrMII(HCO2)6] (AI = NH4H2OI and M = Mn for 1, AI = CH3NH3 I and M = Fe for 2, AI = CH3NH2CH3 I and M = Co for 3, AI = CH3NH3 I and M = Ni for 4). Compounds 1–4 display isostructural niccolite architectures, differing only in the host metal ions and guest amines. Tunable ferromagnetic (FO) strength was achieved in the resulting architecture under the guidance of orthogonal magnetic orbital analysis of host metal ions CrIII and MII ions. The magnetic ordering temperatures for 1–4 are lower than 2, 10.3, 7.6, and 22.0 K, respectively. Notably, thanks to the weak FO coupling between CrIII and MnII ions, 1 displays a large magnetocaloric effect bearing the maximum of magnetic entropy change (−ΔS m max) up to 43.9 J kg–1 K–1 (ΔH = 7 T and T = 3.5 K), larger than most of reported transition-metal-based complexes and commercial gadolinium gallium garnet (Gd3Ga5O12) (−ΔS m max = 38.4 J kg–1 K–1 with ΔH = 7 T). Compared with 1, the increase of the magnetic ordering temperature in 2–4 is due to the increasing strength of FO interactions between CrIII and MII ions. Our work offers an avenue to modulate the strength of FO exchange via analyzing the orthogonal magnetic orbitals of heterometallic ions in octahedral field. Further exploration on this work, including the construction of other heterometallic formate framework templated by distinct amines and the study of potential magnetism and phase transition, are underway.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

A series of heterometallic formate framework templated by distinct amines has been solvothermally prepared. They feature the general formula of [AI][CrMII(HCO2)6] (AI = NH4H2OI and M = Mn for 1, AI = CH3NH3 I and M = Fe for 2, AI = CH3NH2CH3 I and M = Co for 3, AI = CH3NH3 I and M = Ni for 4). Compounds 1-4 display isostructural niccolite architectures, differing only in the host metal ions and guest amines. Tunable ferromagnetic (FO) strength was achieved in the resulting architecture under the guidance of orthogonal magnetic orbital analysis of host metal ions CrIII and MII ions. The magnetic ordering temperatures for 1-4 are lower than 2, 10.3, 7.6, and 22.0 K, respectively. Notably, thanks to the weak FO coupling between CrIII and MnII ions, 1 displays a large magnetocaloric effect bearing the maximum of magnetic entropy change (-ΔS m max) up to 43.9 J kg-1 K-1 (ΔH = 7 T and T = 3.5 K), larger than most of reported transition-metal-based complexes and commercial gadolinium gallium garnet (Gd3Ga5O12) (-ΔS m max = 38.4 J kg-1 K-1 with ΔH = 7 T). Compared with 1, the increase of the magnetic ordering temperature in 2-4 is due to the increasing strength of FO interactions between CrIII and MII ions. Our work offers an avenue to modulate the strength of FO exchange via analyzing the orthogonal magnetic orbitals of heterometallic ions in octahedral field. Further exploration on this work, including the construction of other heterometallic formate framework templated by distinct amines and the study of potential magnetism and phase transition, are underway.

The mixture of Cr­(NO3)3·9H2O (1.2 g, 3 mmol), MnCl2·4H2O (0.39 g, 2 mmol), formic acid (6 mL), formamide (6 mL), and water (3 mL) in a sealed Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel was heated at 70 °C for 2 d and then cooled to ambitent temperature. Rose block crystals of 1 was obtained in an ∼30% yield based on Cr salt. Theoretical EA (%) for C6H12CrMnNO13 (413.09): C, 17.45; N, 3.39; H, 2.93. Experimental: C, 17.63; N, 3.16; H, 3.21.

[CH<sub>3</sub>NH<sub>3</sub>]­[CrFe­(HCOO)<sub>6</sub>] (2)

The synthesis of 2 was similar to that of 1 with temperature 140 °C. FeCl2 (0.25 g, 2 mmol) was used to replace MnCl2·4H2O. Formic acid (7.5 mL) and N-methyl formamide (7.5 mL) were used to replace the mixed formic acid-formamide–water solvent. Rose block crystals of 2 were obtained in an ∼35% yield based on Cr salt. Theoretical EA (%) for C7H12CrFeNO12 (410.01): C, 20.51; N, 3.42; H, 2.95. Experimental: C, 20.23; N, 3.66; H, 3.23.

[CH<sub>3</sub>NH<sub>2</sub>CH<sub>3</sub>]­[CrCo­(HCOO)<sub>6</sub>] (3)

The synthesis of 3 was similar to that of 2, but CoCl2·6H2O (0.48 g, 2 mmol) and dimethylformamide (DMF; 7.5 mL) were used to replace FeCl2 and N-methyl formamide, respectively. Red block crystals of 3 were obtained in an ∼30% yield based on Cr salt. Theoretical EA (%) for C8H14CrCoNO12 (427.13): C, 22.50; N, 3.28; H, 3.30. Experimental: C, 22.72; N, 3.54; H, 3.05.

[CH<sub>3</sub>NH<sub>3</sub>]­[CrNi­(HCOO)<sub>6</sub>] (4)

The synthesis of 3 was similar to that of 2, but NiCl2·6H2O (0.48 g, 2 mmol) was used to replace FeCl2. Rose block crystals of 4 were obtained in an ∼30% yield based on Cr salt. Theoretical EA (%) for C7H12CrNiNO12 (412.86): C, 20.36; N, 3.39; H, 2.93. Experimental: C, 20.54; N, 3.15; H, 3.26.

cln_elements.content: Although the structure of 1 has been reported, the magnetic and magnetocaloric investigation of 1 has not been conducted. Magnetic properties of 1–4 were studied on powder samples, and the phase purity is confirmed by the agreement between experimental PXRD curves and the fitted ones (Figures S1–S3). The magnetic susceptibility (χ) data are characterized in 2–300 K under 1 kOe field. The temperature-dependent χm T plot of 1 is present in a. The experimental χm T product of 6.57 cm3 mol–1 K at 300 K for 1 matches with the spin-only values (g = 2.00) of one isolated CrIII and one MnII. When cooled, the χm T product increases gradually before 40 K, and then it quickly rises to 32.95 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K. The χm data among 2–300 K can be fitted by the Curie–Weiss law, giving C = 6.53 cm3 mol–1 K and θ = 1.53 K (Figure. S4). The small positive θ suggests weak FO interactions in 1. However, no saturation of magnetizations was observed at low temperature under 0.1 T excluding long-range order (LRO) above 2 K. Magnetizations among 2–10 K were also gauged (a). At low fields (<0.5 T), the magnetization at 2 K increases sharply and increases gradually to 7.88 Nβ at 7 T, close to the theoretical value of 8.0 Nβ for one CrIII and one MnII. All of these magnetic behaviors indicate weak FO couplings among neighboring metal ions. The high magnetic density (or large metal/ligand mass ratio) and weak FO interactions between the CrIII–MnII ions in 1 hold great promise for low-temperature magnetic cooler.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Magnetism Studies

Although the structure of 1 has been reported, the magnetic and magnetocaloric investigation of 1 has not been conducted. Magnetic properties of 1-4 were studied on powder samples, and the phase purity is confirmed by the agreement between experimental PXRD curves and the fitted ones (Figures S1-S3). The magnetic susceptibility (χ) data are characterized in 2-300 K under 1 kOe field. The temperature-dependent χm T plot of 1 is present in a. The experimental χm T product of 6.57 cm3 mol-1 K at 300 K for 1 matches with the spin-only values (g = 2.00) of one isolated CrIII and one MnII. When cooled, the χm T product increases gradually before 40 K, and then it quickly rises to 32.95 cm3 mol-1 K at 2 K. The χm data among 2-300 K can be fitted by the Curie-Weiss law, giving C = 6.53 cm3 mol-1 K and θ = 1.53 K (Figure. S4). The small positive θ suggests weak FO interactions in 1. However, no saturation of magnetizations was observed at low temperature under 0.1 T excluding long-range order (LRO) above 2 K. Magnetizations among 2-10 K were also gauged (a). At low fields (<0.5 T), the magnetization at 2 K increases sharply and increases gradually to 7.88 Nβ at 7 T, close to the theoretical value of 8.0 Nβ for one CrIII and one MnII. All of these magnetic behaviors indicate weak FO couplings among neighboring metal ions. The high magnetic density (or large metal/ligand mass ratio) and weak FO interactions between the CrIII-MnII ions in 1 hold great promise for low-temperature magnetic cooler.
